body:
I went to Linux a few years ago as a Windows refugee, knowing that every day that I spent learning how to tweak Windows further was a day wasted in a constant uphill battle just for myself against Microsoft. Linux really didn't appeal to me at first, as I noticed inconsistencies with its UI and the difficulty to pull off certain tasks.

Since I always had a Windows 10 laptop given for work, I never had to be reminded about how bad Windows was (and is) for productivity. Today however, starting at new company, I've been relieved from W10 with a new a Macbook Pro - the latest model, something m1 Big Sur. It's a great design, got a great keyboard, and I'm quite fond of some of the gestures.

But HO-LY are some of the Mac UI/UX inconsistencies never given their spotlight:

* Setup had text overlapping a spinning icon
* Keyboard shortcuts for default apps have me straining fingers (have you SEEN the browser tab switching shortcuts?)
* Resizing windows in default apps permanently makes text stay at "..."
* Terminal can't be closed with Ctrl^C, or Exit
* Majority of actions require mouse/gesture, and take half a second with animations
* Alt-tab can focus closed apps
* None of this is easily customizable
* Plugging in a keyboard makes trackpad gestures unbearable
* You can't do (some parts of) application installs in parallel

And I'm leaving out the design issues that are just my unfamiliarity bias, like the fact that you *need* to use a mouse to navigate around.

I never gave Mac a serious shot before so I wasn't aware of these things compared to Linux, and always assumed it was pretty good, but it shocks me that one of the most user-friendly devices has issues that not even Linux has.

I genuinely believe at this point and time a proper KDE setup has better UX for developers, kids and just about anyone other than computer illiterates alike. Mac has some great features, but is not polished like I always thought.

Anyways, this is a mini-rant break between going through my checklist of things I want to set up for the Mac.

body:
I feel like this post isn't complete without at least crediting some things I believe MacOS does well from a UI/UX standpoint:

* The app Rectangle allows for some pretty intricate tiling, more than I even used on Linux
* The touchbar above the keyboard is very innovative and great
* When you tile an app that doesn't scale, Mac doesn't force it to scale
* The finger scanner en-lieu of password is a life saver (I probably type in my Linux pw 10x a day)

Much like the complaints there's other ones I'm forgetting for sure ;). What's always noteworthy about UX however, is you notice when things are bad- not when they're good. I'm not saying Mac is s#!t (hey, if you're coming from Windows you're about to meet God), but it's not everything I believed it to be, least of all with all the praising people give it.

body:
Everything Apple makes has been shit for the last 2 decades. The problem is they decided they wanted to control everyone so they removed most features and took away most personal settings. With Apple, Apple owns your device, not you. They literally make you pay 10x more for something that's half as capable. Windows was always the better alternative until recently with windows 10 they're starting to go that route too. I've always liked the windows and linux UI better too, I'm not sure what all the fuss about Macs is.

Also *every* modern UI sucks, reason being because everyone is going for that ugly, dull, boring "flat" look which makes no sense now that we have more powerful machines. And like I said they took away all the ways to change anything too. The only solution now is linux with custom themes, and even those are breaking now with newer versions of renderers, so if it wasn't made in the last year you'll probably have to re-make it.
